text: <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation has been implicated in the pathogenesis of RA .
Active <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is constitutively expressed in synovial fluid mononuclear cells from RA patients [ 36 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the major <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activating <extra_id_0> factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> present in synovial fluid , <extra_id_0> which <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has a crucial role in the activation of monocyte functions such as gene expression of the <extra_id_0> Fc gamma receptor type I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> type III <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and of HLA-DR [ 31 ] .

More recently , high levels of activated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , thought to be induced mainly by <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , have been detected in the ST , and <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation has been shown to be involved in synovial fibroblast proliferation and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production [ 37 ] .
In this regard , <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is critical in the survival and expansion of growth factor - dependent synovial fibroblasts [ 38 ] .

Furthermore , the significance of persistent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling in Th1-cell-dominated autoimmune arthritis has been suggested by studies of the <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> F759 / F759 mice , in which the Src homology phosphatase-2 binding site of <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( the <extra_id_0> transmembrane glycoprotein beta subunit of the IL-6 family cytokine receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , tyrosine 759 , was mutated to phenylalanine [ 39 ] .

In the <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> F759 / F759 mice , T cells , particularly the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T-cell subset , are chronically activated and resistant to activation - induced cell death through <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .
The longevity of cytokine signals transduced by the JAK-STAT pathway is regulated by the SOCS family proteins [ 7 ] .

We found that <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from patients with active RA expressed higher levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but lower levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , compared with normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> prevents activation of JAK by directly binding to JAK , and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits the action of JAK by binding to the Src homology phosphatase-2 - binding domain of <extra_id_0> receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> such as <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 40 ] .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are induced by <extra_id_0> various cytokines <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , including <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as mediators of negative feedback and crosstalk inhibition [ 7 ] .

Recent studies with mice lacking <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> revealed that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a negative regulator of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling but not of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling .

Studies of conditional <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice have shown that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiency , but not <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiency , results in sustained activation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in response to <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 8 , 41 ] .

The analysis of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient macrophages has indicated that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a crucial inhibitor of the <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced transcriptional response [ 42 ] .

However , <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is dispensable for both the negative feedback inhibition and the immunoregulatory action of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in macrophages [ 41 ] .
On the contrary , <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found to directly inhibit <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated signaling [ 43 ] .

Increased <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells may therefore be associated with both the impaired responsiveness to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , and defective <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression may be responsible for persistent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation in response to serum <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

There is a possibility that <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction may be associated with the ability of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to produce <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , because <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA could produce high levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and because <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been known as a potent inducer of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 32 ] .

It is of interest in this regard to indicate that polarized Th1 and Th2 cells express high levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , respectively [ 44 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation is inhibited by <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction in Th2 cells , whereas <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling is diminished by <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction in Th1 cells .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may thus have important roles as Th1 - specific and Th2 - specific , mutually exclusive , cross-talk repressors of the <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> STAT6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> STAT4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling pathways , respectively .

Consistent with this notion , PB T cells from patients with allergic diseases significantly express high levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcripts , and the <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression correlates well with serum IgE levels and disease pathology [ 45 ] .

Higher <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression with lower <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from RA patients , compared with healthy controls , is therefore probably consistent with their systemic bias towards a Th1 phenotype , as has previously been demonstrated [ 46-49 ] .
